summary: This is a DOJ Office of the Inspector General interview transcript from July 12, 2021, with a Federal Bureau of Prisons lieutenant who worked at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 9, 2019, the day before Jeffrey Epstein's death. The interview focuses on the lieutenant's duties, knowledge of Epstein's cellmate requirements, rounds and counts in the SHU, and the circumstances surrounding the removal of Epstein's cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, on August 9th.

events.title: DOJ OIG Interview
events.description: The DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, sworn interview with a BOP lieutenant regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein and surrounding circumstances.

locations: Federal Correctional Institution Danbury, Danbury, Connecticut (Interview location)
keyFacts: The interviewee, a BOP lieutenant, was the activities lieutenant at MCC on August 9, 2019, but has limited recollection of specific details from that day, including his exact end time and whether he conducted a round in the SHU.
The lieutenant states he had no conversation with Officer about Nicholas Tartaglione going WAB, contradicting the implication of a memo written by Officer.

Analysis of count slips from August 9-10 suggests counts in the SHU were not properly conducted, with discrepancies (e.g., 73 vs. 72) indicating staff may have been falsifying counts or only doing rounds, not actual counts.

The lieutenant believed Epstein required a cellmate for three reasons: 1) standard SHU policy (unless special status), 2) an email sent when he came off suicide watch, and 3) his presence on the 'hotlist' for suicidal inmates.

The lieutenant opined that the primary failure leading to Epstein's death was the lack of proper 30-minute rounds and counts in the SHU, considering the cellmate issue a secondary, and somewhat inevitable, administrative lapse in a busy jail.
